abstract.p: Defense Department announces that it will award most lucrative fighter jet contract in history, totaling over $200 billion, to either Lockheed Martin or Boeing Co (S)

block.p: The Pentagon announced yesterday that it would award the most lucrative fighter jet contract in history, totaling over $200 billion, to one company -- either Lockheed Martin or Boeing.

The decision ends months of speculation that the Pentagon might split the contract and give a portion to each company. In a letter to Congress yesterday, William S. Cohen, the defense secretary, emphasized that the program, as originally planned, would continue. Then, in a later news conference, Jacques Gansler, the defense under secretary for acquisition and technology, was more explicit, saying that the winner-take-all approach ''makes the most sense to us.''
The Pentagon announced yesterday that it would award the most lucrative fighter jet contract in history, totaling over $200 billion, to one company -- either Lockheed Martin or Boeing.

The decision ends months of speculation that the Pentagon might split the contract and give a portion to each company. In a letter to Congress yesterday, William S. Cohen, the defense secretary, emphasized that the program, as originally planned, would continue. Then, in a later news conference, Jacques Gansler, the defense under secretary for acquisition and technology, was more explicit, saying that the winner-take-all approach ''makes the most sense to us.''
Mr. Gansler did say, however, that the Pentagon had been evaluating ''in-house a set of alternatives'' to this single-company approach before making yesterday's statement.

The move highlights the Pentagon's highly unusual decision to introduce commercial-world practices in the design and production of the next generation of fighter jets, the Joint Strike Fighter, a plane that is being made in three versions, one for each branch of the military. The Pentagon envisions that the plane, a low-cost fighter with stealth capability, will be used by the United States and its allies and expects that more than 2,800 of these aircraft will be made domestically.

By awarding one contract the Pentagon is not only introducing a greater level of competition, but it is also eliminating the possibility that the plane would be constructed by two companies at two production sites -- which might have saved jobs at military contractors but would have increased the program's overall cost.
